You should classify Marksmen into two other categories: Casters and Blasters (But use new names)

Casters are the spellcasting variant that weave autos in addition to spells and their kits primarily focus on the use of spells ({{champion:21}} {{champion:81}} {{champion:236}} )

Blasters would be the auto-focused characters. Sure, they use spells, but their bread and butter in fights is auto-ing as much as possible with the occasional spell thrown in. ({{champion:222}} {{champion:18}} {{champion:67}} )

I think the more sensible subclass split is focusing on _when_ they excel at dealing sustained damage - long range types sieging towers and clearing minions for their team, scrappy types that can deal well with being dived or dueled, or the more tactical type that wear down enemy teams with well-timed spells from afar.

I want it split that way because they _should_ fit in to those categories, not because they do right now.  Any marksman that does two or more of those too well is just way too good at their jobs in general, and having a clear weakness against one of those three situations on every marksman in the game will more clearly lay out what to pick and how to play around them - or against them.

I like this, possibly go with:
Scouts: Use tactical positioning and well placed and timed auto attacks and/or spells to weaken the enemy team. 
Gunslingers: Use above average survivability and various tricks to win fights at close range.
Seigers: Specialize in objective control and applying continuous pressure to specific locations on the map.

For what it's worth though, a decent number of the Marksmen can be played in one or more of these ways based on how you choose to build.  For example, critical strike chance is almost useless for siege focused marksmen, but invaluable for Gunslinger play styles.

I want to define them a little differently though:

Snipers: deal single-target sustained damage from range, and usually have some burst to finish off low targets.

Gunslingers: Have lower range and deal AoE and low-range burst damage. They are often ability focused.

Trackers: have methods to stick to a single target and finish them off. Usually have mobility and CC.

does this mean someone like nidalee may be changed completely so that you cant go ad/bruiser anymore?

Nope.

> But don’t worry, this doesn’t just automatically mean we’re going to overhaul your champion. Most champions also don’t fit perfectly into any specific Subclass - We’ll repeat: the class / subclass structure is more a set of guidelines than rigid rules. Sharing our vocabulary here just means we can have better conversations about the state of the game at any given time.



>  ...it's important to distinguish between a champion's current ‘most effective’ play style and their ideal one. There are a lot of champions whose thematic and/or gameplay mechanics are better suited for a specific subclass, but over the course of time drifted into a different one.

This whole post means that they're setting clearer vocabulary so that we can all speak the same, clear lanauage when we talk about the **ideal** role of every champion in the game.

Nidalee is a Hybrid (As with most/all of the Transformation Champions)- Probably of Assassin and Artillery Mage. This doesn't mean she can't have AD scalings (Like she's had for years an Seasons now).

As they said in this Dev Blog (The second part I quoted), you must distinguish between a Champion's ideal/intended role in the game (Which will be the Class/Subclass) and their currently most effective role (Say it's AD/Diver Nidalee), but that **it doesn't mean every champion will only have one of the two type of Scalings (AP or AD).**

Hopefully this was understandable. :P
